qas.question: Is a person's brain fully developed by the time they reach puberty?
The brain reaches what percentage of its adult size by the time a person is six years old?
The biggest changes in the brain during puberty occur in the parts of the cortex that process what kinds of information?
What parts of the brain continue to become more complex into the late teens?
The brain reaches 90% of its adult size by the time a person reaches what year of age?

context: The human brain is <a0_0>not<a0_0/> fully developed by the time a person reaches puberty. Between the ages of 10 and 25, the brain undergoes changes that have important implications for behavior (see Cognitive development below). The brain reaches <a1_0>90%<a1_0/> of its adult size by the time a person is <a4_0>six<a4_0/> years of age. Thus, the brain does not grow in size much during adolescence. However, the <a3_0>creases<a3_0/> in the brain continue to become more complex until the late teens. The biggest changes in the folds of the brain during this time occur in the parts of the cortex that process <a2_0>cognitive and emotional<a2_0/> information.
